I think the phrasing of hypotonic vs. hypertonic is wrong. Hank says, "if the concentration inside of the cell is lower than outside of the cell, it's called hypotonic." But hypotonic means that the concentration OF SOLUTES inside of the cell is higher, and the concentration of WATER inside the cell is lower. Hypertonic means that the concentration of SOLUTES OUTSIDE the cell is higher than inside the cell, and that inside the cell it's lower. Therefore, the water molecules leave the cell, trying to add itself to the outside of the cell, leaving the solutes behind in the cell.  I don't think he phrased it that way. The explanation and demonstration of hypertonic with the sausage casing at 3:20 is not showing us what Hank says it is. The blue salt water inside represents the cell, and the clear fresh water represents the environment. Tonicity ALWAYS is about the environment; so the salt concentration here is lower (fresh water has less salt), which makes this an example of hypotonic solution. What happens? Water enters the cell (sausage casing) and it swells. Look at the wrinkled casing in his hands and then watch it swell up (no wrinkles) when in the water. So why does the blue move out? The blue dye molecules (not the "salt water" as Hank says) is diffusing out from the high concentration inside toward the low concentration of blue outside. Water is moving in, as shown by the swelling. I love the Crash Course gang, but I had to speak up on this.

Just as a quick help, because i didn't quite understand Hanks explanation (with the example he names, with the salt water): Hypertonic : if the concentration of a solution is higher on the outside than it is on the inside (if they had reversed the process, placed a membrane filled with  water in a saltwater solution, the salt water solution would have been hypertonic) Hypotonic : if the concentration of the solution is lower on the outside than it is on the inside. (With the experiment, the water outside of the membrane was hypotonic, with the salt water, inside the membrane having the higher solution of "salt per water").  Sources: my biology text book, Khan Academy ( https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/membranes-and-transport/diffusion-and-osmosis/v/hypotonic-isotonic-and-hypertonic-solutions-tonicity )

Snow Zhane Echidna hypertonic means there is a high solute concentration (there is more stuff dissolved in the water). Hypotonic means there is a low solute concentration (there is less stuff dissolved in it). For example, the saltwater would be hypertonic compared to the pure water because there is more salt in it. The pure water is hypotonic compared to the saltwater because it has less salt in it

The ATP is on the inside of the cell. It provides the energy for the sodium-potassium pump to keep pumping sodium out and potassium in even though that's against the concentration gradient, if that makes sense. Basically, even though the sodium wants to get into the cell and the potassium wants to get out, the ATP inside the cell provides energy to not only keep them in but keep pumping more potassium in and more sodium out.
